title: 108_hr846
content: The Act may be cited as the "Melanie Blocker-Stokes Postpartum Depression Research and Care Act". Postpartum depression is a mood disorder that affects many women during and after pregnancy. It can be categorized into three subgroups: "baby blues," postpartum mood and anxiety disorders, and postpartum psychosis. "Baby blues" is characterized by mood swings, tearfulness, irritability, poor sleep, and vulnerability. Postpartum mood and anxiety disorders include symptoms like worsening baby blues, postpartum psychosis involves losing touch with reality, and each year over 400,000 women experience mood changes after childbirth. The causes of postpartum depression are complex and not fully understood, with theories pointing to hormonal changes post-delivery. Postpartum depression can be caused by a rapid drop in hormone levels after childbirth, difficulty during labor or pregnancy, a premature birth, or a lack of support from spouse, friends, or family. It is treatable with a personalized regimen of care including social support, therapy, medication, and sometimes hospitalization. Postpartum depression often goes undiagnosed or untreated due to social stigma, the myth of motherhood, and economic pressures. Untreated, it can lead to further depression, substance abuse, loss of employment, and impact society through the infant's well-being. Child abuse, neglect, or death of the infant or siblings can impact the infant's physical and psychological development, as well as disrupt the family. Research on postpartum depression and psychosis is being expanded and intensified by the National Institute of Mental Health. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, through the National Institute of Mental Health, is expanding research on postpartum depression and psychosis. Coordination with other national research institutes is required, and programs for postpartum conditions will be conducted or supported. The Director of the Institute conducts or supports research on postpartum conditions, including basic research, epidemiological studies, diagnostic techniques development, clinical research for new treatments, and information/education programs. Authorization of appropriations is provided for these purposes. Authorized appropriations for fiscal years 2004 through 2006. Establishment of program of grants for delivery of services regarding postpartum depression and psychosis. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide grants for projects to establish systems for delivering services to individuals with postpartum conditions. Grants can be given to public or nonprofit entities, including hospitals, community organizations, and health centers. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide grants for projects to establish systems for delivering services for postpartum conditions. Projects may include outpatient and home-based health services, inpatient care management, and improving the quality of healthcare services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide grants for projects to establish systems for delivering health care and support services for individuals with postpartum conditions and their families. The program will be integrated with other grant programs carried out by the Secretary. SEC. 202. CERTAIN REQUIREMENTS. Under section 201, a grant requires the applicant to agree to specific conditions: 1) Limiting administrative expenses to 5%, 2) Using the grant to supplement, not replace, other funds for postpartum treatment, 3) Following Secretary-imposed limitations on charges for services, and 4) Not using the grant for services already covered under section 201(a). The applicant must post notices about federal policies regarding charges for services provided under section 201(a) at each service site. The Secretary may provide technical assistance to help entities comply with requirements to be eligible for grants under section 201. Authorization of appropriations is available for fiscal years 2004 through 2006 to carry out this title.
